title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Cameroon in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameron signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements.   The total estimated suspension amount was $93,865,000 ($45,167,000 in principal payments and $48,698,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.    Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Cameroon. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Cameroon secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Cameroon in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameron signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements.   The total estimated suspension amount was $93,865,000 ($45,167,000 in principal payments and $48,698,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.    Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement is a financial arrangement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension, financial terms, no project-specific environmental elements

title: Chinese Embassy in Cameroon donates Covid-19 medical supplies to Cameroon National Radio and Television (CRTV) in December 2021
description: On December 10, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon donated medical materials and office supplies to Cameroon National Radio and Television (CRTV) to defend Covid-19. Chargé d'Affaires Wang Dong attended the material handover ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Cameroon donates Covid-19 medical supplies to Cameroon National Radio and Television (CRTV) in December 2021

# Description
On December 10, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon donated medical materials and office supplies to Cameroon National Radio and Television (CRTV) to defend Covid-19. Chargé d'Affaires Wang Dong attended the material handover ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Medical materials and office supplies for Covid-19 response, no energy or environmental components

title: National Health Commission of China donates a batch of Covid-19 medical supplies to Ministry of Health in Cameroon in March 2021
description: On March 15, 2021, the National Health Commission of China to Cameroon donated a batch of medical equipment to fight the Covid-19 pandemic at the Yaounde Central Hospital. Guo Jianjun, Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon, participated in the handover ceremony and signed the handover certificate with Hassan, Director of the Cooperation Department of the Ministry of Health of Cameroon.   This batch of equipment was donated by the National Health and Sanitation Committee of China to the Ministry of Health of Cameroon under the cooperation mechanism of 30 Chinese-African counterpart hospitals (the Chinese and Cameroonian hospitals are respectively the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University and the Central Hospital of Yaoundé), including respiratory machine, expectoration machine, electrocardiogram machine, blood oxygen saturation monitor and oxygen generator.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
National Health Commission of China donates a batch of Covid-19 medical supplies to Ministry of Health in Cameroon in March 2021

# Description
On March 15, 2021, the National Health Commission of China to Cameroon donated a batch of medical equipment to fight the Covid-19 pandemic at the Yaounde Central Hospital. Guo Jianjun, Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon, participated in the handover ceremony and signed the handover certificate with Hassan, Director of the Cooperation Department of the Ministry of Health of Cameroon.   This batch of equipment was donated by the National Health and Sanitation Committee of China to the Ministry of Health of Cameroon under the cooperation mechanism of 30 Chinese-African counterpart hospitals (the Chinese and Cameroonian hospitals are respectively the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University and the Central Hospital of Yaoundé), including respiratory machine, expectoration machine, electrocardiogram machine, blood oxygen saturation monitor and oxygen generator.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment for healthcare purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical equipment including respiratory machines, oxygen generators, and monitoring devices for Covid-19 response

title: Chinese medical team donates medical supplies to local hospitals in Cameroon in July 2021
description: On July 26, 2021, the 21st Chinese (Shanxi) medical team to Cameroon donated medical supplies to the local women and children's hospital in Yaoundé, the capital of Cameroon. At the ceremony held at Yaoundé Women and Children's Hospital, the Chinese medical team donated 55 categories of medicines and medical equipment including ophthalmology, stomatology, acupuncture and moxibustion to the hospital.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese medical team donates medical supplies to local hospitals in Cameroon in July 2021

# Description
On July 26, 2021, the 21st Chinese (Shanxi) medical team to Cameroon donated medical supplies to the local women and children's hospital in Yaoundé, the capital of Cameroon. At the ceremony held at Yaoundé Women and Children's Hospital, the Chinese medical team donated 55 categories of medicines and medical equipment including ophthalmology, stomatology, acupuncture and moxibustion to the hospital.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of medical supplies to local hospital, healthcare focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 300,000,000 grant via May 2021 ETCA for multiple development projects in Cameroon
description: On May 4, 2021, China and Cameroon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) in the form of an unrequited donation in the amount of 300,000,000 RMB, or about 25,500,000,000 CFA francs. It will make it possible to finance development projects to be identified by mutual agreement.
combined_text:
# Sector
UNALLOCATED/UNSPECIFIED

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 300,000,000 grant via May 2021 ETCA for multiple development projects in Cameroon

# Description
On May 4, 2021, China and Cameroon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) in the form of an unrequited donation in the amount of 300,000,000 RMB, or about 25,500,000,000 CFA francs. It will make it possible to finance development projects to be identified by mutual agreement.
justification: General development funding without specific project details or environmental focus
evidence: Unspecified development projects, grant funding mechanism

title: Chinese medical team provides TCM training to Cameroon medical professionals in December 2021
description: On December 15, 2021, two members of the 21st Chinese medical team of Cameroon provided a day-long lecture on traditional Chinese medicine usage. The lecture included training on acupuncture, herbal medicines, massages, exercise, and dietary therapy. The lecture took place at the Gynaeco-Obstetric and Paediatric Hospital in Yaoundé, the capital of Cameroon. 50 Cameroonian doctors and nurses attended the training. The monetary value of this training is unknown.  Tian Yuan, the head of the Chinese medical team in Cameroon, stated that the training was part of efforts by China to promote the use of TCM in Cameroon's healthcare system.

title: Chinese Government donates 150,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $2.7 million in July 2021
description: On March 3, 2021, the Chinese Ambassador to the Central African Republic announced that his government would donate a batch of COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Central African Republic. Then, on July 6, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 150,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Central African Republic.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the month year donation as $2.7 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 150,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $2.7 million in July 2021

# Description
On March 3, 2021, the Chinese Ambassador to the Central African Republic announced that his government would donate a batch of COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Central African Republic. Then, on July 6, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 150,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Central African Republic.
justification: Project involves donation of vaccines for public health purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 150,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines, healthcare sector focus

description: On May 15, 2021, the Chinese Embassy donated office supplies to the Central African Republic Ceremony Bureau. The Chinese Ambassador to the Central African Republic, Chen Dong, presented the office supplies to the Director of the Ceremony Bureau, Mapuka. The specific office supplies and their monetary value is unknown.

title: Chinese Ministry of Public Security provides police materials to the Central African Republic Ministry of Internal Affairs and Public Security in December 2021
description: On December 21, 2021, the Chinese Ministry of Public Security donated police materials to the Central African Republic Ministry of International Affairs and Public Security. The Chinese Ambassador, Chen Dong, attended the handover ceremony and signed the handover certificate with the Central African Republic Minister of Public Security, Nassan. The specific materials and the monetary value are unknown.

title: Chinese Embassy donates teaching materials to the China Central Africa Excellent Primary School in August 2021
description: On August 17, 2021, the Chinese Embassy provided teaching materials to the China-Central Africa Excellent Primary School. Shan Chenglin, the Chinese Embassy Political Counselor, presented Chinese cultural books, school bags, workbooks, pencils, and other teaching materials to the school's students. The donation will contribute to the Chinese Embassy's efforts to introduce Chinese culture in local schools and support the development of the Central African Republic.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates teaching materials to the China Central Africa Excellent Primary School in August 2021

# Description
On August 17, 2021, the Chinese Embassy provided teaching materials to the China-Central Africa Excellent Primary School. Shan Chenglin, the Chinese Embassy Political Counselor, presented Chinese cultural books, school bags, workbooks, pencils, and other teaching materials to the school's students. The donation will contribute to the Chinese Embassy's efforts to introduce Chinese culture in local schools and support the development of the Central African Republic.
justification: Project focuses on educational support and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of teaching materials, focus on education and cultural exchange
